email.title: Weekly Digest

image.alt: Chocolate chip biscuits and coffee grains
image.title: A stack of biscuits, with one popped off the stack and bitten

email.text:
Welcome to the second digest of the year!
We've got some great events prepared for you this week, including our annual Sponsors' Exhibition!
email.heading: Autumn Elections - Year Rep Nominations Open
email.text:
Nominations in the Union Autumn elections are **NOW OPEN** and close at **noon on Tuesday 13 October**!
It is an opportunity to make your voice heard within the College and the Union.
Every year students vote for an Academic Year Representative and Wellbeing Year Representative.
The Academic Year Representative receives and collates feedback from their cohort, passing this information to the Departmental Representatives or staff as appropriate. Academic Representatives have made long-lasting improvements in many areas such as the content of curricula, feedback quality and timeliness, exam timetables and formats, and online learning resources.
Wellbeing Year Representatives are part of the Wellbeing Representation Network, which aims to tackle issues such as stress and pressure, mental health, the quality of personal tutoring, how students are supported to be resilient and independent, transitioning back into study after time off, and more. Wellbeing Representatives will work with College staff, Welfare Officers, and Academic Representatives.
Year reps make **real change within the department**, with a place on regular Staff Student Committee meetings, voicing their concerns to teaching fellows and staff.
To nominate yourself and for more information on the mentioned and other roles available, visit the Union's [Autumn Elections page](https://www.imperialcollegeunion.org/news/autumn-elections-2020).
email.heading: Virtual Sponsors' Exhibition

event.text:
This year, our flagship Sponsors Exhibition that attracts over 500 students each year has gone virtual, here on Hopin!
Whether you are looking for an internship or graduate role, or simply want to know more about industry, we really recommend you come along and tune in as it‚Äôs a great way to get in direct contact with recruiters and engineers from highly regarded companies and should provide invaluable insight into the recruitment process.

email.heading: Mums and Dads Pub Quiz

event.text:
It's time for DoCSoc's Mum's and Dad's first meet up! Come along to meet your families and engage in a competitive PUB QUIZ üçª with the other families! This is a great opportunity for freshers to ask any questions they might have and be introduced into DoC.
Keep an eye out for prizes for the top 3 teams!!
Links will be posted on Facebook closer to the time.
Mums and Dads parent? Be sure to turn up to this event to meet your children!

email.heading: Python 101

event.text:
One of the key attributes DoCSoc hosts is the Python 101 Introductory Workshop for not only DoC students, but all members of Imperial College London. We invite everyone from any disciplines and level of education. This will be a beginners level course for anyone who has very little to none knowledge in Python. Please click "Going" on Facebook so we can estimate the size of the interactive workshops.
Dates: every Tuesday 4-6pm GMT from Oct 20th to Nov 24th
Syllabus:
* Oct 20th - Introduction, variables, user I/O
* Oct 27th - Control Flow (if statements, for and while loops), lists and list comprehension
* Nov 3rd - Error Handling, Imports, Functions, Recursion (?)
* Nov 10th - Advanced control flow (break, continue, pass), Data Structures (Tuple, Dictionary, Set), Plotting data w/matplotlib
* Nov 17th - Assert, Classes with OOP, Lambdas
* Nov 24th - (extra session) Q&A, Fundamentals of CS (theoretical, more for 1st year Computing)

email.heading: Netcraft ‚Äì Applications of Computing in Industry Talk
email.sponsor:
Netcraft will be giving an ACI talk on Tuesday about the final year project of an ex-DoCSoc student made in partnership with Netcraft and now integrated in our systems. Netcraft have found that criminal infrastructure often purports to be located in jurisdictions with less effective legal systems, uncooperative law enforcement or anonymous company registrations. In reality, the infrastructure is often located in countries with good Internet connectivity and reasonable legal systems, like the Netherlands. In this talk, James will discuss the development of the system, its deployment at Netcraft, and some of the engineering challenges which have been overcome.
If you‚Äôre interested in a career with Netcraft or collaborating on a final year project with us and want to find out more about what we do and how to apply, please check out our recruitment brochure at: https://www.netcraft.com/NetcraftRecruitmentBooklet.pdf
email.heading: Bloomberg Masterclass ‚Äì A New Era Of Python Parsing
email.sponsor:
Date: Wednesday, 14 October 2020
Time: 15:00-16:00 London Time
Apply: via [Yello](tinyurl.com/y6jbwy6t)
The Parser was one of the first pieces that were created for Python and it has served very efficiently for many years; but implementing new rules in the language syntax is becoming more difficult or even impossible in some cases.
In this talk, we will explain the problems with the old parser, how the new parser works, what are its benefits, and what to expect from the Python grammar in the future.
email.heading: Shape your world with Bank of America
email.sponsor:
Technology touches everything we do and underpins each deal we make. In fact, our mainframe environment is the third largest in the world. That said, we don‚Äôt believe that there is a tech ‚Äòtype‚Äô. You don‚Äôt need finance experience to join us and D&I is at our core. Our Global Technology and Operations (GT&O) division gives our business the competitive edge to solve business problems by delivering high quality and practical solutions.
Join our Meet the Technology Teams session to speak directly to members of our Imperial Tech School Team. The event will provide an open forum where you will have the opportunity to ask questions on a range of topics including careers in Global Technology, how to apply and general working life at Bank of America. Please come prepared with your questions to be addressed at this session.
Register your interest [here!](https://bankcampuscareers.tal.net/vx/lang-en-GB/candidate/postings/5855)
Let‚Äôs shape the world together
Date: 21st October, 2020
Time: 14:00 ‚Äì 15:00 (GMT+1)
email.heading: London Stock Exchange Group Events and Opportunities
email.sponsor:
**London Stock Exchange Group ‚Äì Grow your career at market speed.**
London Stock Exchange Group **(LSE.L)** has a long, prestigious heritage that few organisations around the world can rival, dating back to 1698. Since then, we have grown to become one of the world‚Äôs foremost financial market infrastructure and capital markets groups, and a global leader in new financial technology (FinTech). Headquartered in London, our geographic footprint extends to more than 25 cities worldwide, and more than 60 nationalities are represented by our 5000-strong workforce.
We understand that this is a challenging and unprecedented time for everyone, but our graduate and internship programmes ‚Äìand the development of new talent ‚Äìremains critical to our future business success. As we continue to expand and diversify, we are looking for the next generation of talented, ambitious graduates to help us shape the future of LSEG. You will get direct exposure to the exciting innovations happening within finance and technology, putting your ideas and problem-solving skills to use and helping to drive our growth.
_You can find more information about LSEG events and opportunities in pdfs attached to this email._
email.heading: Jane Street Estimathons 2020!
email.sponsor:
**What is an Estimathon?!**
The Estimathon is a team-based contest that combines trivia, game theory, and mathematical thinking. Teams have 30 minutes to work on a set of 13 estimation problems, the winning team being the one with the best set of estimates. Since debuting the Estimathon in 2013, Jane Street has run over 200 Estimathon contests.
The answer to each problem is a positive number. Your team will submit intervals for each problem. Intervals may not contain negative numbers or zero.
You may not use the internet, or your calculator/smartphone, or any other type of external reference material.
**Scoring**
An interval is good if it contains the correct answer. After the 30 minutes is over, the final score for your team will be:
![(10 + sum of (floor of (max / min)) over good intervals) * 2 ^ (13 - # of good intervals)](https://i.imgur.com/yAJFK2G.png)
That is, for every problem you get wrong (or leave blank), your score doubles.
The winning team is the team with the LOWEST SCORE.
**Submitting intervals**
Every team can submit up to 18 total intervals. Submit your intervals at any time throughout the contest. There will be a scoreboard that will be updated in real time based on the intervals that are being submitted.
**Re-submitting**
Given that each has 18 answers and that there are only 13 problems, it is possible to submit intervals for a given problem more than once. If you do this, only the last submission for any given problem is the one that will count towards your final score. To put it another way: each submission (right or wrong) overrides any previous submissions for a given problem.
If you could like to take part in one of our online Estimathons or CEstimathons (where questions are based on the world of computing and trivia) please visit our events page to register or click on the dates below. You can register as a team of 3-5 or as an individual and we will assign you a team on the day - please note that all team members are required to register for the event.
**Dates:** [13th October 2020](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSclzmHOuHCg44bv2we3cKMImo161tsZmlxbMZmLBq-S7hiCZw/viewform?usp=sf_link) (Estimathon), [27th October 2020](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfMZvqD518v2cEfj8ITT2P8DppnX-V8KeLx7qVHrfC2zoKSjw/viewform?usp=sf_link) (CEstimathon) and [11th November 2020](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdByJvJPCXX9UM3dT_9jk3oaJfHa3nhaAIU4akqpclIPmNWOQ/viewform?usp=sf_link) (Estimathon) \ **Time:** 18.00-19.00 BST
email.heading: Palantir Virtual Autumn Events
email.sponsor:
**[Palantir](https://www.palantir.com/students/)** will be hosting a series of virtual events over the next few weeks to help students learn more about Palantir‚Äôs work, opportunities and to prep for applying to open positions. To sign-up, please register using **[this link](https://fall2020eventsemea.splashthat.com/)** and the password `20HobbitFallEMEA`. More info on the specific events below!
**Panel Q&A: The Ins & Outs of Palantir‚Äôs Interview Process:** Whether you‚Äôve already applied to Palantir or you are considering starting an application, we invite you to join us a for a panel discussion where we demystify Palantir‚Äôs interview process and provide tips on how you can prepare! You‚Äôll hear from interviewers, hiring managers, recruiters and engineers who‚Äôve all gone through our interview process and landed a gig at Palantir. Attendees will walk away with tangible learnings that can be applied to their own interviewing experiences this recruiting season.
**Info Session: Palantir 101 + Product Demo** is an opportunity to learn more about Palantir straight from the source. Government agencies, commercial institutions, and non-profit organizations must wrangle an ever-growing amount of data ‚Äì raising important ethical questions for software companies like Palantir that help these institutions harness data to advance their missions. But because Palantir is not a consumer-facing company, it‚Äôs not always easy to understand what we build and how our products are used. Here‚Äôs your chance to learn more directly from our software engineers. Engineers will share how their focus has shifted completely in the last 6 months to help in the fight against COVID-19 on a variety of different fronts. We‚Äôll be sharing demos of our products and answering questions about Palantir and our engineering role.
